bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, May 13, 1924

div1.p: [Carter] discusses the nature of the fever at Bucaramanga, Colombia.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, May 13, 1924
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
Russell
/LH
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
May 13, 1924.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Referring to your letter of May 8th., enclosing copy of Hanson's
of April 4th, which, more or less, brings the nature of the fever
about Bucaramanga in question:

Naturally, I accepted the diagnosis of the White Board, which
saw it and pronounced it yellow fever.

Yet for the difficulty that may occur in the differentiation
between yellow fever and relapsing fever. I would invite your at-
tention to Pp. 53 and 54 of my MSS (which you have) and also to a
report from West Africa (French?) you sent me last summer, of an unnamed spirochetosis, which,
from that report at least, could not have been differentiated from
yellow fever and which, spite of the denial of the reporter, I am
inclined to think was the spirochetosis of Obermeier.

Hanson reported last fall finding spirochetes of Obermeier in
cases reported to him as yellow fever. This naturally threw some
doubt on the nature of the previous fever and I wondered if White's
party had an opportunity to examine patients in different stages
of their sickness or whether they had to depend on the reports of
others. If the latter, anyone might err in diagnosis; as witness
witness
-2-
the West African cases alluded to above. This too, might happen
to myself unquestionably, if I saw a patient in only one stage (or
maybe stages) of his illness and had not opportunity to follow him
through it.

After seeing Hanson's report last fall, I sent him a brief
abstract of the papers referred to in my MS and expressed my opinion
that the “Matlazuhuatl” of the Mexican plateau and the similar epi-
demics on that of the Andes (which gave rise to reports of yellow
fever at Quito and Cerro de Pasco) were of the same nature and cau-
tioned him against placing too much confidence in black vomit and
bleeding gums in a cold climate as unfailing signs of yellow fever.

Naturally, if tick-borne the same disease could occur in hot
countries.

Independently of the clinical determination, however, would
not the positive determinations obtained by Porthier with cultures
of Leptospira icteroides at Bucaramanga be sufficient basis for ac-
cepting the diagnosis of yellow fever? I thought so after I had
received a copy of his report--in December, I think, or later.
Would it be reasonable that such reactions would be given by any
other infection, even if the parasite causing it were of the same
general family, as would be, I suppose, the spirochete of Obermeier?
Also, would it not have been impossible for Porthier to have missed
the spirochetes of Obermeier? They have been much in evidence in
the few cases I have seen, both from their number and motion.

Leaving the nature of the fever of last summer sub judice I
cannot but think there was yellow fever. But for the seriological
I am exceedingly glad that there seems to be no y.f. visible now.
I cannot but think that there was y. f., although but for the seriological
seriological
-3-
reactions, of the value of which you are a better judge than I, I
would doubt it. Both diseases might have coexisted.

p.del:
I am exceedingly glad that there seems to be no yellow fever
visible now.

div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Dr. F. F. Russell, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
